description: Prior to opening as a public park in 1905, Springfield Park was the private garden for three mansion houses of which only one remains. Along with Springfield House, the park is home the refurbished stables and our new venue, The Glass House

factsheet.heading: Springfield Park
paragraphs: In 1902 the land that now comprises the park was put up for sale. This resulted in a campaign to raise money and London County Council (LCC) to buy the land to create a park for the local populace. The purchase of the park by the Council was finalised in 1904.

The park was designed by J.J Sexby, who was the Chief Officer of the LCC Parks Department.  The main alterations involved in creating the park included the removal of two of the large houses and ancillary buildings, and the diversion of Spring Lane which, at that time, ran through the centre of the park.  Other additions included alterations to the path network and the pond with a creation of an island and the construction of a bowling green.

factsheet.heading: Springfield House
paragraphs: Built in 1820 as a grand house with a large garden for the Bros Family, the Grade II listed Springfield House has served park visitors since the opening of the park in 1905.
Over a century of use took its toll on the building which left it in need of intervention to prevent further degradation.

The sympathetic restoration brought parts of the house back into use by creating a new annex to house toilets and cafe kitchen. The first floor which was previously unfit for use is now offices for Hackney Staff.

factsheet.heading: The Glass House
paragraphs: Originally the site of the Kitchen Garden for Springfield House, there were glasshouses here since 1894. In the early years of the public park it was used to raise bedding plants.
By 1989, a very large glasshouse had been erected filling the Kitchen Garden and for some years this was open to the public as a Winter Garden.
In 2001, Growing Communities opened the Springfield Park market garden north of the Kitchen Garden and used the greenhouses for vegetable production until they were declared unsafe in 2009.
This brand new state of the art venue is a breathtaking community venue available for weddings, civil ceremonies, community classes, meetings and special events all year round.

factsheet.heading: The Stables
paragraphs: The Stable Block which formerly served Springfield House has been fully restored and converted to provide new workspaces.
Prior to restoration, the Stables were used by the Gardeners as welfare facilities, office and storage space.
Parts of the first floor were rarely used and the roof required significant work to secure the building from the elements - and the pigeons.
The Stables are now available as creative workspaces which are managed by Mill Co.
